summary:
With 19+ years of professional experience in the space sector, and having worked in various ESA directorates (Technical, Earth Observation, Science, and Exploration), I am passionate about space technology, its development and management. I thrive leading the implementation of technology activities with oversight on the whole value-chain from R&D to flight systems, and its applications.

As a lead technology engineer, I am responsible for supporting the programme management with the definition of technology requirements and scoping activities, implementation of industrial contracts, coordination of technology developments and roadmapping, overseeing the end-to-end technology process. I am a member of the ISECG inter-agency Technology Working Group (e.g. Co-chair of the Autonomy, ISRU, and ECLSS gap assessment teams), and the Technology Network Exploration deputy-chair at ESA.

Throughout my career I have conducted project management of various advanced space technologies in the field of Optical Communications, Optics, Optoelectronics, Contamination Control, GNC sensors, Robotics, ISRU, and Fuel Cells.

Overall I have supported various ESA missions, in the fields of: Re-entry Technology (EXPERT), Telecommunications (ARTEMIS), Education (STRAPLEX), Earth Observation (ADM-Aeolus, EarthCARE, MSG), Science (JUICE) and Robotic Exploration (MSR, EL3, ISRU-DM) during various development phases, e.g. Feasibility, Definition, Implementation, and Exploitation.

I also had the honour to receive the 2018 ESA Team Award for the Aeolus development and laser support teams.

treasury_media.title: The European Space Agency (ESA)
treasury_media.description:
The European Space Agency (ESA) is Europe's gateway to space. Its mission is to shape the development of Europe's space capability and ensure that investment in space continues to deliver benefits to the citizens of Europe and the world.

ESA is an international organisation with 22 Member States. By coordinating the financial and intellectual resources of its members, it can undertake programmes and activities far beyond the scope of any single European country.

treasury_media.title: European Space Research & Technology Centre
treasury_media.description: ESA has sites in several European countries, but the European Space Research and Technology Centre (ESTEC) in the Netherlands, is the largest. ESTEC is our technical heart - the incubator of the European space effort - where most ESA projects are born and where they are guided through the various phases of development.

awards.title: WIRE16 Innovation Award
awards.description: The Innovation Award went to Andrea Lombardo, Ernesto Palomba and Fabrizio Dirri who designed a sensor CAM (Contamination Assessment Microbalance) developed by INAF-IAPS in Rome in collaboration with the CNR-IIA, the Polytechnic of Milan, and Kayser Italia. The sensor is based on a microbalance Quartz crystal, capable of measuring the masses of contamination species up to a billionth of a gram. The applications that this sensor can serve range through the extent of contamination in space, the monitoring of fine dust particles in urban environments and measurements related to volcanic risks. Such work was developed under an ESA contract funded by the Science Core Technology Programme.
